ghostPost.plaintext:
Andrew McLaughlin is President & COO of Assembly OSM [http://assemblyosm.com/],
a new, fast-growing, venture-backed startup working to transform the way we
build high-rise residential architecture. Using advanced digital design and an
innovative, manufacturing-based direct-to-fabrication-and-assembly delivery
system, Assembly OSM is building greener, higher-quality, more affordable
housing in dramatically less time than conventional construction.

Andrew is a co-founder and partner at Higher Ground Labs
[https://www.highergroundlabs.com/], a startup accelerator and venture investor
that backs and builds for-profit startups that help progressives win election
campaigns and policy fights.  Since 2017, Higher Ground Labs has seed-invested
in more than 36 startups, and led a number of Series A rounds and follow-on
financings.

Andrew is a venture partner at betaworks [http://betaworks.com/], a technology
and media startup studio and seed investor based in NYC. As a partner at
betaworks from 2012-2016, Andrew was an operator, a company and product builder,
a business strategist, and an early-stage tech investor. He served as CEO of two
betaworks companies, Digg [http://digg.com/] and Instapaper
[http://www.instapaper.com/], and in 2016 worked at Medium [https://medium.com/]
, leading a set of teams including corporate development, new business
initiatives, editorial, outreach, international, and enterprise services. From
2012-2019, Andrew served on the board of Chartbeat [http://chartbeat.com/], a
real-time data analytics service founded at betaworks.

Andrew chairs the board of Access Now [https://www.accessnow.org/], a
not-for-profit devoted to defending and extending the digital rights of
activists, journalists, and citizens at risk around the world. He is a director
of Public Knowledge [http://publicknowledge.org/], which promotes freedom of
expression, an open Internet, and a vibrant public domain.

In 2018, Andrew joined the board of the Electric Coin Company
[https://electriccoin.co/], which builds and supports technology for Zcash
[https://z.cash/], a decentralized, privacy-protective digital currency built on
remarkably strong cryptographic science.  Zcash is the first widespread
implementation of zk-SNARKs [https://z.cash/technology/zksnarks/], a powerful
form of zero-knowledge cryptography.

In 2017-18, Andrew was the founding executive director of the Tsai Center for
Innovative Thinking at Yale [http://city.yale.edu/], a new, university-wide
initiative to support students across disciplines to tackle real-world problems
in innovative ways.  Tsai CITY is a transformative addition to the Yale campus,
dedicated to advancing the university's goal [http://president.yale.edu/goals] 
of creating an interdisciplinary learning environment that cultivates
innovators, leaders, pioneers, creators, and entrepreneurs in all fields and for
all sectors of society. Through a wide range of programs, intensives, and
initiatives, Tsai CITY coaches and supports students as they conceive, research,
develop, prototype, test, build, iterate, and launch their visions -- whether a
for-profit startup, a mission-driven nonprofit, a social justice movement, or an
experimental theater company.

From 2009-2011, Andrew was a member of President Obama
[https://barackobama.com/]'s senior White House staff, serving as Deputy Chief
Technology Officer of the United States.  In that role, Andrew was responsible
for advising the President on Internet, technology, and innovation policy,
including open government, cybersecurity, online privacy and free speech,
spectrum policy, federal R&D priorities, entrepreneurship, and the creation of
open technology standards and platforms for health care, energy efficiency, and
education.

In 2008-2009, he served on the Obama/Biden presidential transition team
[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Presidential_transition_of_Barack_Obama], as a
member of the Technology, Innovation and Government Reform
[https://www.youtube.com/watch?time_continue=1&v=InI5n3NTvR4] cluster.  In
2015-16, Andrew was a member of the human rights and tech & innovation advisory
committees of Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign.

From 2003-2009, Andrew was Director of Global Public Policy
[http://googlepublicpolicy.blogspot.com/] at Google [http://google.com/],
leading the company's work on issues like freedom of expression and censorship,
surveillance and law enforcement, privacy, copyrights and trademarks, regulation
of Internet and telecommunications networks, wireless radio spectrum, national
security, trade policy, patent reform, and online child protection. Google’s
first public policy hire, Andrew established, built and managed a 50-person
worldwide team based in Brussels, London, Paris, Madrid, Milan, Berlin,
Amsterdam, Stockholm, Dublin, Brasilia, Buenos Aires, Tokyo, Seoul, Beijing,
Sydney, Ottawa, Washington, and San Francisco. Beyond policy, Andrew was a
co-lead on Google's Africa [http://google-africa.blogspot.com/] strategy and
operations.

From 1999-2003, Andrew helped launch, establish, and manage ICANN
[http://www.icann.org/], the Internet's technical coordinating organization,
serving as Vice President, Chief Policy Officer, and Chief Financial Officer.
From 1998-2005, Andrew was a Senior Fellow at Harvard Law School
[http://law.harvard.edu/]'s Berkman Center for Internet and Society
[http://cyber.law.harvard.edu/]. In 2002-2003, Andrew taught a course on digital
democracy at Harvard Law School while working on Internet and telecom law reform
projects in a number of developing countries, including Ghana, Mongolia, Kenya,
Afghanistan, and South Africa. He was a co-founder of CIPESA
[http://www.cipesa.org/], a technology policy think-tank and advocacy center
based at Makerere University [http://mak.ac.ug/] in Uganda. Andrew served as a
member of the Board of Directors of Bridges.org
[http://www.ethanzuckerman.com/blog/2014/01/14/rest-in-peace-teresa-peters/], an
international technology policy not-for-profit based in Cape Town.

From 2011-2012, Andrew was EVP of Tumblr [http://tumblr.com/], responsible for
the international, community, outreach, editorial, marketing, and support teams.

Andrew is a member of the advisory board of Swing Left [https://swingleft.org/],
which was founded in 2016 to help Americans everywhere work effectively to flip
the U.S. House to a Democratic majority.

Andrew is a Future Tense Fellow [http://futuretense.newamerica.net/] at the New
America Foundation [http://newamerica.net/]; an advisor to Data & Society
[http://www.datasociety.net/], a research institute focused on social, cultural,
and ethical issues arising from data-centric technological development; a member
of the Advisory Council of the Open Technology Fund
[https://www.opentech.fund/about/people]; a co-chair of the digital strategy
committee of the Brooklyn Public Library [https://www.bklynlibrary.org/]; and a
member of New York Public Radio [https://www.wnyc.org/]’s Digital Task Force. He
has served as a member of the Partnership for New York City’s Innovation Council
[http://innovateinnyc.org/].

Andrew served on the boards of Code for America [http://codeforamerica.org/] 
(2011-13) and the Sunlight Foundation [http://sunlightfoundation.com/],
(2011-2016). In 2014-15, he was a senior fellow in cybersecurity and Internet
governance at Columbia University [http://www.columbia.edu/]'s School of
International and Public Affairs [https://sipa.columbia.edu/]; in 2011-12, he
was a non-resident fellow at Stanford Law's Center for Internet & Society
[http://cyberlaw.stanford.edu/] and at Princeton's Center for Information
Technology Policy [https://citp.princeton.edu/]. In 2011-12, Andrew was a
Lecturer in Law at Stanford Law School [http://www.law.stanford.edu/], teaching
a course
[http://blogs.law.stanford.edu/newsfeed/2011/05/05/andrew-mclaughlin-to-join-center-for-internet-society-as-non-residential-fellow/] 
on "Freedom of Speech in a Digitally Interconnected World". In 2011-13, Andrew
was a member of the Commission on Innovation
[http://www.bbg.gov/press-release/bbgs-commission-on-innovation-holds-first-meeting-in-new-york/] 
of the U.S. Broadcasting Board of Governors [http://www.bbg.gov/].

After clerking on the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit
[http://www.ca8.uscourts.gov/], Andrew started his career as a lawyer at Jenner
& Block in Washington, D.C., where he focused on appellate and constitutional
litigation. He was a member of the legal team that challenged the U.S.
government's first Internet censorship law, resulting in the Supreme Court's
landmark 1997 Internet free speech ruling in Reno vs. ACLU
[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reno_v._American_Civil_Liberties_Union]. From
1997-98, Andrew served as legal counsel in the U.S. House of Representatives
[http://www.house.gov/].

In 2000, Time Magazine [http://time.com/] named Andrew one of its Digital Dozen
for the new century. In 2001, he was named a Global Leader for Tomorrow by the 
World Economic Forum [http://www.weforum.org/]. He is a fellow of the Young
Leaders Forum [http://www.ncuscr.org/ylf] of the National Committee on US-China
Relations [http://www.ncuscr.org/].

Andrew holds a B.A. in history from Yale University [http://www.yale.edu/], and
a J.D. from Harvard Law School [http://law.harvard.edu/].

Growing up, Andrew attended Highland Elementary School
[http://www.sylvaniaschools.org/highlandelementary_home.aspx] in Sylvania, Ohio; 
Widsten Elementary School
[https://www.swnewsmedia.com/lakeshore_weekly/news/local/widsten-school-the-pueblo-on-the-hill/article_d7787085-8305-5366-8249-bd409a4da107.html] 
in Wayzata, Minnesota; Longfellow Elementary School
[https://www.fargo.k12.nd.us/longfellow] and Ben Franklin
[https://www.fargo.k12.nd.us/benfranklin]Junior High School
[http://library.ndsu.edu/fargo-history/?q=content/benjamin-franklin-school] in
Fargo, North Dakota; the American Community School
[https://www.acs-schools.com/cobham] in Cobham, Surrey, UK; and Neil A.
Armstrong Senior High School [http://ahs.rdale.org/] in Plymouth, Minnesota,
from which he graduated in 1987.  Over summers, he attended the Trollwood
Performing Arts School [http://www.trollwood.org/] in Fargo, the International
Music Camp [http://www.internationalmusiccamp.com/] in Dunseith, North Dakota,
and the Minnesota Institute for Talented Youth [http://www.mity.org/] in St.
Paul, at which point he had to start working summer jobs at places like the 
Sheraton Park Place Hotel [http://slphistory.org/sheratonparkplace/], Dayton's
Department Store [http://lileks.com/mpls/daytons/index.html], and the kitchen of
the celebrated Red Lobster of Golden Valley
[http://www.yelp.com/biz/red-lobster-golden-valley].

Current + evergreen obsessions:

 * Cities, architecture, urbanism, transit, civic tech, economic opportunity,
   and sustainability.
 * The Internet, tech, artificial intelligence and machine learning, startups,
   consumer and SaaS product design, the media industry, business strategy, and
   global scaling.
 * Public policy, constitutional law, free speech, privacy, rule of law, and
   democratic vitality.
 * Progressive politics, political theory and philosophy, American and world
   history.
 * Books, bikes, beagles.
